Award.AwardTitle: An Examination of Science and Technology Teachers' Conceptual Learning through Concept-Based Engineering Professional Development

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Technology educators from Black Hills State University (SD) and Purdue University partner with science educators from the University of Massachusetts at Boston and Stevens Institute of Technology to determine the viability of an engineering concept-based approach to teacher professional development for secondary school science teachers in life science and in physical science. The project refines the conceptual base for engineering at the secondary level learning (previously developed by the PIs) to increase the understanding of engineering concepts by the science teachers. In a pilot test of two weeks of professional development with ten teachers from each discipline, teachers become familiar with engineering concepts and study the process of infusing engineering concepts into science curricula so that they can develop modules in their discipline to be taught during the following in the school year. The following summer the teachers debrief the process and develop additional modules for their discipline. The process is revised and repeated with 22 teachers from each discipline. Teachers are explicitly provided strategies to help them meet the needs of diverse learners. The outputs of this project include: 1) a preliminary framework for secondary level engineering education to be published in both research and practitioner journals; 2) a pilot tested and validated Engineering Concept Assessment; 3) engineering-infused curriculum modules in life and physical science; and 4) a professional development model to prepare science teachers to infuse engineering in their teaching.

The project compares student learning when particular concepts in physics and biology are taught through engineering design with learning the same concepts taught an earlier group of students with present reform techniques used in the discipline. The hypothesis is that when teachers and students engage with engineering design activities their understanding of science concepts and inquiry are also enhanced. The research component of the project employs an iterative design with the design of activities followed by development and implementation. An engineering concept assessment is developed and tested to examine teacher learning and to determine how engineering concepts can be infused into the science curricula for life and physical science. Other quantitative and qualitative instruments are developed to assess the teachers? understandings of the engineering concepts and their pedagogical implications.

There is increasing emphasis on integrative STEM education. New national and international assessments are developing engineering strands and emphasizing non-routine problem solving. The framework for the Next Generation Science Standards includes engineering as one of four strands. Stand alone engineering course are not likely to be widely used. This project develops engineering infused science units and determines the professional development needed to use them effectively.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of Project INFUSE was to examine the viability of an engineering concept-based approach to teacher professional development within the life and physical sciences. The project engaged in research and education activities including: refining a conceptual base of engineering for secondary level learning; preparing the professional development activities designed to develop teachers' understanding of engineering concepts and engage the teachers in a process of curriculum concept infusion; and developing instrumentation to collect data on the teachers' understandings of the engineering concepts and how this impacts their teaching.

Intellectual Merit: The intellectual merit of the project was based on a conceptual base consisting of a set of core engineering concepts for secondary-level science. Developed through engagement with the literature, engineering professionals, educators, the conceptual base served as the foundation for the project?s activities and outcomes. The concepts include:

  • Design (constraints, tradeoffs, optimization, prototyping)
  • Analysis (life-cycle, cost-benefit, risk)
  • Systems (structure, functions, interrelationships)
  • Modeling (visualization, prototyping, mathematical models)

Key observations from the project included: the importance of engagement with engineering-based and standards-aligned curriculum materials; significant duration of professional development including ongoing involvement with teachers including school year; the identification and use of a set of core engineering concepts, the use of a clearly defined set of elements to structure the professional development, and the intensive and ongoing use of reflection throughout the professional development.

Broader Impacts: The broader impacts of this project include publications (books and journal articles), presentations and documented experiences with science teachers. These include:

Summer Institutes. The project conducted a series of four summer institutes with cohorts of secondary level physics and life sciences teachers. The first two institutes were designed to pilot-test a set of key professional development activities and the second two involved a scale up to a larger group of teachers. The institutes were designed to provide an engineering concept-based approach to professional development and were designed to build on each other, moving from a broad introduction to engineering concepts embedded within science lessons to more in-depth and reflective engagement during the second year. A set of key elements provided structure for the institutes and included engagement with engineering case studies; concept mapping; draft engineering-infused science module planning; discussions of how to infuse engineering concepts into science instruction; engagement with engineering infused lessons; and pedagogical reflections.

School Year Activities. Professional development for teachers continued throughout the academic year during which time teachers delivered engineering infused lessons to secondary students. These lessons were video-taped and innovation configuration maps were used to develop video clips for use as analytical tools during the second summer institute. All teachers implemented at least one infused lesson/unit during the year. Other key components of the school year activities involved reflective analysis of implementation, discussions of engineering assessment, and additional explorations of engineering concepts.

Innovation Configuration (IC) Map. The map contains three broad dimensions including curriculum and two focused on teacher practices. All three dimensions contain sub-dimensions and descriptive statements designed to depict the extent to which teachers? practices and curriculum selections align with engineering-oriented science instruction. This proved to be a valuable tool for helping teachers think through an engineering concept-based approach to science learning in more depth. It also helped to structure the professional development by visualizing and communicating what an engineering approach can and should look like in real classrooms.

Engineering Concept Assessment (ECA). The Engineering Concept Assessment (ECA) instrument was designed to measure the teachers? understanding of the study?s core engineering concepts. The instrument was developed using established procedures for high stakes testing including the development of standards statements and specific expectations for each concept at two different levels of conceptual difficulty. Item analyses were conducted and engineering content experts were engaged to examine and refine every item on the instrument in preparation for use during the scale up phase of the project. The goal was to have 6 items for each of the 4 engineering concepts that ranging across Bloom's taxonomy levels. The ECA was used to assess the extent to which the professional development experiences impacted science teachers' conceptual understanding of engineering.

Books Published by the National Science Teachers? Association (NSTA). Two books were published by the National Science Teachers Association (NSTA) based on work with science teachers throughout the professional development. These are entitled Engineering in the Life Sciences: 9-12 and Beyond the Egg Drop: Infusing Engineering into High School Physics. The books are directly based on the lessons learned from Project Infuse and were designed to address a need for standards-based, engineering-oriented materials. The need was particularly acute with the life sciences where there are few materials available to help teachers understanding how engineering can be incorporated into their classes. The books include contextual overview of the role of engineering, lessons and lesson ideas, assessment and classroom management information and case studies.

Modified by: Rodney L Custer

The books are directly based on the lessons learned from Project Infuse and were designed to address a need for standards-based, engineering-oriented materials. The books include contextual overview of the role of engineering, lessons and lesson ideas, assessment and classroom management information and case studies.
